conclusion: We are given the p-V diagram showing states A, B, and C. The temperature of the gas at state C (Tc) is 300 K. Use the ideal gas law: \( pV = nRT \), where \( n \) is the number of moles, \( R \) is the universal gas constant, and \( T \) is the temperature. Since the amount of gas (n) and the gas constant (R) remain the same for states A, B, and C, we can use the relationship \( \frac{p_1 V_1}{T_1} = \frac{p_2 V_2}{T_2} \).
At state C: Pressure \( p_C = 5 \times 10^5 \) Pa, Volume \( V_C = 2 \times 10^{-3} \) m³. At state B: Pressure \( p_B = 2 \times 10^5 \) Pa, Volume \( V_B = 5 \times 10^{-3} \) m³.

premise: Using the equation: \( \frac{p_B V_B}{T_B} = \frac{p_C V_C}{T_C} \). Substitute the values for states B and C.
Simplify both sides of the equation: \( \frac{10 \times 10^2 \text{ Pa·m}^3}{T_B} = \frac{10 \times 10^2 \text{ Pa·m}^3}{300 \text{ K}} \)
Since the numerator is the same on both sides, equate the denominators.
